Cook Islands: Public Finance Management and

Director  R. K. Leonard, South Pacific Subregional Office, PARD

Team members  E. Ferguson, Senior Country Specialist, PARD

A. Pala, Assistant Project Analyst, PARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Cook Islands requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  conduct  an  assessment  of  the  country’s  public  service.  The 
assessment was undertaken in November 2009 under the TA for Public Sector Review and 
Improvement approved on 16 October 2008 for $240,000. The outcome of the assessment was 
a comprehensive approach to support implementation of the recommendations to improve the 
efficiency of the public sector in the Cook Islands.  
 
2.  The assessment was based on a review of (i) the current macroeconomic situation; 
(ii) the legal and regulatory environment including the Public Service Commission (PSC) Act, 
2009; the Ministry of Finance and Economic Management Act, 1995-96; the Public Expenditure 
Review Committee and Audit Act, 1995-96; and the Cook Islands Investment Corporation Act, 
1998; among others; (iii) established public service management processes, procedures, and 
policies; and (iv) past studies on public sector-related issues. Consultations were also held with 
key stakeholders in government and the community. The findings of the assessment were 
reviewed  with  the  National  Sustainable  Development  Committee  (NSDC) 1 and  relevant 
government stakeholders. 
 
3.  An ADB fact-finding mission was conducted in March 2010 to reach an understanding 
with  the  government  on  the  objectives  and  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and the detailed terms of reference for consulting services of the 
proposed policy and advisory TA. The TA has been included in the TA program for 2010 in 
ADB’s  country  operations  business  plan,  2010–20122 and  is  consistent  with  the  strategic 
objectives of The Pacific Approach 2010–2014.3 The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The Cook Islands undertook a major public sector and economic reform in 1995–1996 
because of a financial crisis that had its roots in an expanding public sector, a limited private 
sector resource base, and a rapidly increasing debt burden. The number of ministries and civil 
service personnel was reduced by about one third. Debt was restructured, with ADB playing the 
role of “honest broker,” and legislation designed to ensure better public financial management 
(para. 2) was adopted. The resultant growth dividend saw average growth of 6% gross domestic 
product (GDP) per annum from 1999 to 2004. However, more recently, minimal infrastructure 
investment (in part influenced by the need to bring debt back under control), the impact of 
several cyclones, high inflation, and the global economic crisis have resulted in economic 
contraction.   
 
5.  The government recognizes that a renewed public sector reform program is essential to 
turn around this economic situation. Raising performance and productivity—vital for achieving 
the needed large capital investment program—is the focus. In FY2010, the cabinet imposed a 
2% expenditure cut, mainly in operations. Personnel costs and numbers remained about the 
same and personnel expenditure is expected to reach 45% of total revenue in FY2011. This 
                                                
1  The NSDC comprises the chief of staff (chair); financial secretary; public service commissioner; solicitor general – 
Crown Law; secretary, Ministry of Foreign Affairs; and manager, Aid Management Division, Ministry of Finance and 
Economic Management. The secretariat is provided by the Office of the Prime Minister. 
2  ADB. 2009. Country Operations Business Plan: Cook Islands, 2010–2012. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2009. ADB’s Approach to Assisting the Pacific (2010–2014). Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 April 2010.

2   
increase has eroded some of the reductions accrued during 1995–2000. Revisions to the Manila 
Agreement5 financial ratios have been approved as a policy action under ADB’s Economic 
Recovery Support Program.6 This commits the government to the following: (i) tax revenue 
should not exceed 25% of GDP unless it is due to better compliance and efficiency, (ii) public 
sector wages and salaries should be 44% of total revenue and are to be reduced to 40% in the 
out-years, (iii) debt servicing should not exceed 5% of total revenue, (iv) the overall deficit 
should not exceed 2% of GDP, and (v) net debt should not exceed 35% of GDP. 
 
6.  Prior to the 1995–1996 reforms, government personnel numbered 3,200. This reduced 
significantly to 1,868 in 1996 and continued to decline to 1,866 in 2006 and 1,792 in 2009. 
Despite  this,  the  public  service  grew  as  a  portion  of  the  total  workforce  to  18%  in  2006 
compared to 16% in 1996. The ratio of population per public sector employee decreased from 
9.7 in 1996 to 7.4 in 2006 as the population declined due to out-migration. Public sector costs 
and personnel increases are made more affordable by the increased number of tourists to help 
finance the size and scope of public services (tourist numbers have more than doubled since 
the mid-1990s to reach about 100,000 per year).  
  
7.  There has been no review of the size, structure, and functions of the public service since 
decentralization  during  the  1995–1996  reforms.  According  to  the  findings  of  the  2009 
assessment,  various  entities  have  arisen  on  a  needs  basis—resulting  in  segmented 
management, accountability, and performance structures. In addition:  
(i)  Outer island administration and activities were devolved to the outer islands 
under the Ministry of Outer Island Development during the reforms. However, in 
1998, police, justice, health, and education services were recentralized to the 
Rarotonga-based ministries resulting in dispersed planning and accountability in 
outer island development.  
(ii)  There  is  a  lack  of  synchronization  between  existing  planning,  management, 
financing,  implementation,  and  monitoring  activities;  and  a  lack  of  linkages 
between budget monitoring and performance monitoring.  
(iii)  The  absence  of  a  public  administrative  manual  for the  whole  public  service 
means  that  the  advice  given  on  public  service  policies,  operations,  and 
processes is ad hoc and piecemeal—prompting ministries to develop their own 
manuals, which results in inconsistencies between ministries. 
 
8.  Efforts to improve public sector performance in terms of improving planning capacities 
include the adoption of the National Sustainable Development Plan, 2007–2010 (NSDP); the 
conduct of sector and multiyear planning tied to the annual budget process; establishment of 
performance contracts and plans with heads of ministries and island administrators; and the 
development of a medium-term budget framework (MTBF). The government has started public 
administration  reform  by  improving  the  legal  and  regulatory  environment  and  adopting  a 
performance  management  approach.  More  is  to  be  done  to  ensure  full  implementation  of 
legislation,  strengthening  coordination  between  the  central  agencies,  and  expanding  the 
                                                
5  The 1998 Manila Agreement was signed between the governments of Italy, Nauru, and New Zealand to facilitate 
restructuring of the unsuccessful commercial ventures made by the Government of the Cook Islands in the early 
1990s which resulted in a fiscal crisis at the time. 
6  ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Program Cluster 
and Loan for Subprogram 1 to the Cook Islands for the Economic Recovery Support Program. Manila (Loan 2565-
COO, approved on 13 October, for $10 million).

3 
coverage  of  the  PSC  Act,  2009  to  crown  agencies,7 especially  in  terms  of  performance 
management oversight and accountability. 
 
9.  The government needs to be of a size that is affordable, efficient, accountable, and 
responsive to its medium-term objectives. Given recent and current revenue streams and a 
growing budget deficit, it is questionable if the size of the public service is affordable. Citizens, 
including the private sector, are questioning whether such increases have contributed to more 
effective and efficient service delivery. There is a common public belief that the reform attitude 
resulting from the 1995–1996 efforts has dissipated.  
 
10.  The tight current and expected future fiscal situation makes apparent the need for a 
more measured approach to avoid the crisis-driven changes of 1995–1996. If public sector 
reform is not addressed in a stepwise comprehensive manner, the country may confront a 
similar situation as in the mid-1990s and be forced to make drastic changes that may result in 
severe out-migration.  
 
11.  Given the fiscal environment, changes in the country’s socioeconomic makeup, and 
more emphasis on performance management and medium-term budgeting, it is timely to look 
again at the size, scope, and performance of the government. The public service assessment 
conducted under the TA for Public Sector Review and Improvement found that there is a need 
to review the size of the public sector and align its structure and scope to national priorities, 
advance performance management government-wide, and initiate an enabling environment for 
enforcing comprehensive public service regulations and policies.  
 
12.  The  public  service  assessment made  the following recommendations:  (i)  conduct  a 
government-wide functional analysis to redefine the government’s size and scope; (ii) include 
crown agencies under the performance elements of the PSC Act, 2009; (iii) address outer island 
administration in terms of improving service delivery in an accountable manner; (iv) improve 
performance management so there is more collaboration between ministries and agencies and 
simplified planning and monitoring process in line with the annual budget, and eventually the 
MTBF and linked to the NSDP; (v) develop a performance-oriented framework for state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs) and assess the rationalization prospects of these and other government 
commercial activities; (vi) develop a public service policies, standards, and guidelines manual, 
and  review  and  improve  the  remuneration  process;  and  (vii)  provide  ongoing  public 
administration training. The assessment’s recommendations should be implemented in a staged 
approach in keeping with government capacities and available resources. The proposed TA will 
cover public administration reform aspects, while the rationalization of SOEs will be addressed 
separately. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The expected impact of the policy and advisory TA will be a government structure that is 
cost-effective  and  aligned  to  national  priorities.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  policy  and 
advisory TA will be a set of options for priority public administration reforms made available to 
the government. 
                                                
7  Crown agencies include three central oversight offices (Audit Office, Ombudsman, and Crown Law Office) and 
others that are supported by their own legislation and do not fall under the PSC Act except for Section 8 regarding 
some employment policies and standards. The Cooks Islands currently has 14 ministries and 13 crown agencies.

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The policy and advisory TA will (i) conduct a government-wide functional analysis to 
redefine government’s size and scope; (ii) review how to include crown agencies under the 
performance elements of the PSC Act, 2009; (iii) address outer island administration in terms of 
improving service delivery in an accountable manner; (iv) improve performance management for 
more collaboration between ministries and agencies and a simplified planning and monitoring 
process in line with the annual budget and eventually the MTBF and linked to the NSDP; and (v) 
develop  a  public  service  policies,  standards,  and  guidelines  manual.  It  will  support  the 
adjustments  the  PSC  is  making  to  achieve  its  mandate  and  the  regulatory  framework, 
processes, and procedures in place to advance public sector management and performance.  
 
15.  The TA outputs include (i) a functional analysis of government agencies completed and 
adopted; (ii) central government agencies (PSC, Office of the Prime Minister [OPM], and the 
Ministry of Finance and Economic Management [MFEM]) implement a coordinated planning, 
management, and monitoring system; and (iii) a public administrative manual enabling the PSC 
to enforce regulations submitted for approval.  
 
16.  Review size of the public sector to align national priorities. The TA will support a 
functional  analysis  of  the  public  service  including  outer  island  administrations  and  crown 
agencies. It will also help identify services that can be more efficiently and effectively provided 
by the private sector. The TA will support the preparation of a costed redundancy program for 
potential displaced public servants as a result of the proposed functional analysis. The TA will 
assist  in generating the  needed  political  and  public  understanding  of the  rationale for  the 
recommended changes. The NSDC will provide oversight for the functional analysis to include 
ministries, departments, and crown agencies (not SOEs). A secretariat, with PSC coordinating, 
will also be formed consisting of PSC, MFEM, and OPM representatives to support the work of 
the international and local counterpart team. 
 
17.  Advancing  performance  management  government-wide.  The  TA  will  support 
(i) consolidating,  aligning,  and  simplifying  the  current  different  planning,  management,  and 
monitoring systems with the NSDP and MTBF; and (ii) strengthening the collaboration between 
the  central  agencies  (PSC,  MFEM,  and  OPM)  so  that  performance-oriented  planning  and 
monitoring  is  done  in  an  efficient  manner  using  the  human  resources  available  and  not 
overburdening ministries and agencies. 
 
18.  Initiating an enabling environment for enforcing comprehensive public service 
regulations  and  policies. The TA will advance the preparation of standard public service 
administration policies across government to be submitted for approval and adoption. It will 
assist the PSC to produce a single operations manual consisting of a set of public service 
policies, standards, and guidelines in a consolidated manner for all ministries and agencies.  
 
19.  It is envisaged that the implementation of the recommendations delivered under this TA 
will be carried out under separate follow-on TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the policy and advisory TA is estimated at $375,000 equivalent, of 
which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and 
administered by ADB.  The government will finance the equivalent of $75,000 in kind through

5 
the provision of counterpart staff, office accommodation, and local communication services. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The PSC will be the executing agency for the TA. All TA components will require the 
cooperation of the MFEM and OPM in particular, and other ministries, agencies, and outer 
island administrations as relevant. 
 
22.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from December 2010 to November 2011. It 
will require 6 person-months of an international consultant in the areas of public sector reform 
and organizational development, and 8 person-months of a national consultant in public sector 
organizational assessment. The consultants will carry out the activities as defined in the terms 
of reference (Appendix 3). The consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time 
to time). Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as amended from time to time) and will be handed to the government on completion of the TA. 
The government will ensure that all required counterpart staff, other human resources, and 
support facilities will be available to the consultants in a timely manner. The proceeds of the TA 
will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
23.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, lessons, and steps leading 
to the next phase. Throughout the TA, the team leader will submit (via e-mail) brief monthly 
progress reports summarizing TA activities, progress, issues, and constraints. Team members 
will produce reports on their respective activities for the team leader’s progress and final reports. 
The team leader’s final report will be submitted in draft form at least 5 weeks prior to the end of 
the assignment, and the final report within 2 weeks of receipt of comments by the government 
and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 to the Government 
of the Cook Islands to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Public Finance Management and Public Sector Performance Review, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General Description of Consulting Services 
 
1.  The  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  (i)  conduct  a  government-wide 
functional analysis to redefine government’s size and scope; (ii) review how to include crown 
agencies under the performance elements of the Public Service Commission (PSC) Act, 2009; (iii) 
address  outer  island  administration  in  terms  of  improving  service  delivery  in  an  accountable 
manner; (iv) improve performance management so there is more collaboration between ministries 
and agencies and a simplified planning and monitoring process in line with the annual budget and 
eventually  the  medium-term  budget  framework  and  linked  to  the  National  Sustainable 
Development Plan; and (v) develop a public service policies, standards, and guidelines manual. A 
proposed follow on TA will be the implementation phase and will (i) review and improve the 
remuneration  process,  (ii)  provide  ongoing  public  administration  training,  and  (iii)  develop  a 
performance orientation for state-owned enterprises and assess the rationalization prospects of 
state-owned enterprises and other government commercial activities.  
 
B.  Detailed Terms of Reference 
2.  The required consulting inputs for the different clusters and time frames are indicated below.  
 
1.  Public Sector Reform and Organizational Development Specialist and Team 
Leader  (international,  6  person-months  [5.5  months  field,  0.5  home  office], 
intermittent over a 12-month period) 
 
(i)  Assess  the  size,  cost,  and  personnel  allocations  of  the  various 
ministries/departments  and  crown  agencies  by  first  determining  the  necessary 
functions of respective departments and/or sectors. 
(ii)  Identify  areas  where  duplication  of  effort  can  be  eliminated  and  consolidation, 
streamlining and contracting out can occur to achieve cost efficiencies and improve 
public service effectiveness. 
(iii)  Review outer island administrations, functions, and roles. With the PSC, identify a 
more responsive management and accountability approach. 
(iv)  Recommend  realignment  options  for  a  more  efficient  structure  for  government 
ministries  and  agencies  by  identifying  organizational  structures,  functions, 
personnel, and other needs. 
(v)  Review the PSC Act 2009 to determine approaches to include crown agencies 
under the PSC Act, especially related to accountability sections. Advise on ways to 
adjust the PSC Act, as deemed appropriate.  
(vi)  Prepare a costed redundancy program to deal with misplaced workers.  
(vii)  Present findings and recommendations to the National Sustainable Development 
Committee. 
(viii)  Manage team and liaise with the PSC and other government stakeholders. 
(ix)  Conduct  information  gathering  and  presentation  workshops  with  public  service 
personnel and other relevant stakeholders. 
(x)  Prepare necessary project related reports to include an inception report with a TA 
work  program,  monthly  status  reports,  a  draft  final  report,  and  final  report.  In 
addition, a preliminary findings paper during the first stage of the functional analysis 
and  a  final  National  Sustainable  Development  Committee  accepted  public 
administration rightsizing plan.

10  Appendix 3 
 
3.  Qualifications: Bachelors or masters degree or equivalent in public administration; at least 
10 years experience working on international public administration reform projects including at 
least 3 years in a team leader position and at least 3 years cumulative experience working with 
Pacific Island country governments.  
 
2.  Public Sector Organizational Assessment Adviser (national, 8 person-months 
over a period of 12 months) 
 
(i)  Work with the team leader to conduct government-wide functional analysis. 
(ii)  Help gather ministry/agency information, assess information, and advise on ministry 
and agency activities. 
(iii)  Contribute to preparing a costed redundancy program based on experience in the 
Cook Islands and country systems and processes. 
(iv)  Maintain  liaisons  with  key  stakeholders  in  government  and  civil  society.  Help 
conduct  project  workshops  with  government  participants  and  other  key 
stakeholders. 
(v)  Contribute to project reporting as needed.  
 
4.  Qualifications:  Bachelors  or  masters  degree  or  equivalent  in  economics  or  public 
administration; at least 10 years experience working in a Cook Islands government entity at a 
senior level as well as at least 5 years other work experience. The adviser can be seconded from a 
government entity. Experience working in the Cook Islands’ private sector is an advantage.
